messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 62 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Approximation Algorithms for Minimizing Congestion in Demand-Aware Networks This project is supported by the European Research Council (ERC), grant agreement No. 864228 (AdjustNet) Horizon 2020, 2020-2025, and supported in part by NSF grants CCF-1909111 and CCF-2228995. Long Luo is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (62102066), National Key Research and Development Program of China (2023YFB2904600), and Young Elite Scientists Sponsorship Program by CAST (2022QNRC001).

Paper Abstract: Abstract Emerging reconfigurable optical communication technologies allow to enhance datacenter topologies with demand-aware links optimized towards traffic patterns. This paper studies the algorithmic problem of jointly optimizing topology and routing in such demand-aware networks to minimize congestion, along two dimensions: (1) splittable or unsplittable flows, and (2) whether routing is segregated, i.e., whether routes can or cannot combine both demand-aware and demand-oblivious (static) links. For splittable and segregated routing, we show that the problem is generally 222-approximable, but APX-hard even for uniform demands induced by a bipartite demand graph. For unsplittable and segregated routing, we establish upper and lower bounds of O‚Äã(log‚Å°m/log‚Å°log‚Å°m)ùëÇùëöùëöO\left(\log m/\log\log m\right) and Œ©‚Äã(log‚Å°m/log‚Å°log‚Å°m)Œ©ùëöùëö\Omega\left(\log m/\log\log m\right), respectively, for polynomial-time approximation algorithms, where mùëöm is the number of static links. We further reveal that under un-/splittable and non-segregated routing, even for demands of a single source (resp., destination), the problem cannot be approximated better than Œ©‚Äã(cmaxcmin)Œ©subscriptùëêsubscriptùëê\Omega\left(\frac{c_{\max}}{c_{\min}}\right) unless P=NP, where cmaxsubscriptùëêc_{\max} (resp., cminsubscriptùëêc_{\min}) denotes the maximum (resp., minimum) capacity. It remains NP-hard for uniform capacities, but is tractable for a single commodity and uniform capacities. Our trace-driven simulations show a significant reduction in network congestion compared to existing solutions.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 62 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 62"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The future of optical interconnects for data centers: A review of technology trends",
        "c-through: part-time optics in data centers",
        "Helios: a hybrid electrical/optical switch architecture for modular data centers",
        "A survey of reconfigurable optical networks",
        "Projector: Agile reconfigurable data center interconnect",
        "High throughput data center topology design",
        "Stable matching algorithm for an agile reconfigurable data center interconnect (MSR-TR-2016-1140)",
        "Cerberus: The power of choices in datacenter topology design (a throughput perspective)",
        "Duo: A high-throughput reconfigurable datacenter network using local routing and control",
        "Mars: Near-optimal throughput with shallow buffers in reconfigurable datacenter networks",
        "Dynamic demand-aware link scheduling for reconfigurable datacenters",
        "Efficient non-segregated routing for reconfigurable demand-aware networks",
        "Characterizing the algorithmic complexity of reconfigurable data center architectures",
        "On the complexity of non-segregated routing in reconfigurable data center architectures",
        "Survey of reconfigurable data center networks: Enablers, algorithms, complexity",
        "Scheduling for weighted flow and completion times in reconfigurable networks",
        "Scheduling opportunistic links in two-tiered reconfigurable datacenters",
        "Demand-aware network design with minimal congestion and route lengths",
        "Improved scalability of demand-aware datacenter topologies with minimal route lengths and congestion",
        "Load-optimization in reconfigurable networks: Algorithms and complexity of flow routing",
        "Dynamic load balancing in hybrid switching data center networks with converters",
        "Approximation algorithms",
        "Scheduling techniques for hybrid circuit/packet networks",
        "Costly circuits, submodular schedules and approximate carath√©odory theorems",
        "Edge 640 optical circuit switch",
        "Series 6000n network optical matrix switch",
        "Firefly: a reconfigurable wireless data center fabric using free-space optics",
        "Augmenting data center networks with multi-gigabit wireless links",
        "RUSH: routing and scheduling for hybrid data center networks",
        "Achieving efficient routing in reconfigurable dcns",
        "The Design of Approximation Algorithms",
        "A randomized rounding approach to a k-splittable multicommodity flow problem with lower path flow bounds affording solution quality guarantees",
        "Hardness of approximating problems on cubic graphs",
        "Flows on few paths: Algorithms and lower bounds",
        "Computers and Intractability: A Guide to the Theory of NP-Completeness",
        "The nature of data center traffic: measurements & analysis",
        "Inside the social network‚Äôs (datacenter) network",
        "Network traffic characteristics of data centers in the wild",
        "On the complexity of traffic traces and implications",
        "Characterization of the doe mini-apps",
        "pfabric: minimal near-optimal datacenter transport",
        "Jellyfish: Networking data centers randomly",
        "Rotornet: A scalable, low-complexity, optical datacenter network",
        "Expanding across time to deliver bandwidth efficiency and low latency",
        "Sirius: A flat datacenter network with nanosecond optical switching",
        "A scalable, commodity data center network architecture",
        "Xpander: Towards optimal-performance datacenters",
        "Splaynet: Towards locally self-adjusting networks",
        "Jupiter evolving: transforming google‚Äôs datacenter network via optical circuit switches and software-defined networking",
        "Integrating microsecond circuit switching into the data center",
        "Analyzing the communication clusters in datacenters",
        "Competitive analysis for online scheduling in software-defined optical WAN",
        "Improving scalability in traffic engineering via optical topology programming",
        "Optflow: A flow-based abstraction for programmable topologies",
        "Chopin: Combining distributed and centralized schedulers for self-adjusting datacenter networks",
        "Optimizing multicast flows in high-bandwidth reconfigurable datacenter networks",
        "On efficient oblivious wavelength assignments for programmable wide-area topologies",
        "Shortest paths in a hybrid network model",
        "A bounding box overlay for competitive routing in hybrid communication networks",
        "Fast hybrid network algorithms for shortest paths in sparse graphs",
        "Near-shortest path routing in hybrid communication networks",
        "Computing shortest paths and diameter in the hybrid network model"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 62 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Approximation Algorithms for Minimizing Congestion in Demand-Aware Networks This project is supported by the European Research Council (ERC), grant agreement No. 864228 (AdjustNet) Horizon 2020, 2020-2025, and supported in part by NSF grants CCF-1909111 and CCF-2228995. Long Luo is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (62102066), National Key Research and Development Program of China (2023YFB2904600), and Young Elite Scientists Sponsorship Program by CAST (2022QNRC001)., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
